metadata.case_name: Petitions under Articles 32 and 136 of the Constitution against judgments of Hyderabad High Court
metadata.case_number: Petitions Nos. 12, 13, 14 of 1951 (Art. 32); Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 14, 15, 16 (Art. 136)

facts.text: On 30th October 1948, Military Governor of Hyderabad enacted Special Tribunals Regulation No. 5 of 1358 F, amended on 22nd May 1949, 10th July 1949, 23rd July 1949, 30th October 1949.
Regulation empowered Military Governor to constitute Special Tribunals of three members to try offences before or after commencement; Section 8 allowed delegation to other authorities.
Tribunal A constituted for Nalgonda district; Civil Administrator of Nalgonda made over cases to it under powers from Military Governor.

Criminal Case No. 14 of 1949 based on charge sheet No. 14 dated 7th April 1949 by Mr. Hanumantha Naidu: Accused (Communists) in khaki uniform with unnotified firearms went to village on 21st September 1948, caught four persons for not paying subscription, decoyed and killed them by cutting throats.

Criminal Case No. 17 of 1949 based on charge sheets Nos. 14 and 15 dated 20th July 1949: On 6th April 1949 at 9 A.M., two accused fired guns in village, ran away, joined others; all marched on villagers, fired indiscriminately; one villager died from thigh injury, another minor hand injury. Trial version: Chased by 50-100, fired after parley, chased back.

Criminal Case No. 18 of 1949: On 15th May 1949 midnight, accused in khaki with firearms to Kasthala village, caught Natala Rama Reddy from terrace, took to outskirts despite protests, killed by gunshots.
Petitioners convicted of murder and sentenced to death by Tribunal A; also convicted of other offences including carrying unlicensed firearms, various imprisonment terms.
Petitioners appealed to Hyderabad High Court; convictions and sentences confirmed by judgment dated 19th December 1950 (M. Khaliluzzaman Siddiqi J. in Misc. Petitions 2297-2299/1950).
Applied for leave to appeal to Judicial Committee of Hyderabad; pending when Constitution came into force 26 Jan 1950; amended to seek leave under Art. 134(1)(c); rejected.
Supreme Court special leave under Art. 136 dismissed as no jurisdiction over pre-26 Jan 1950 Hyderabad HC judgments.
Applied to Hyderabad HC under Art. 226; rejected.
Civil Administrator letter No. 3176/49-ST dated 7th April 1949 made over charge sheets 1-14 to Tribunal.
Civil Administrator letter No. 4234/49-ST dated 23rd July 1949 made over charge sheets 15-40 to Tribunal.
No specific order found for charge sheet No. 14 dated 20th July 1949 (Case 17); prima facie not made over.
In Cases 17 and 18, accused not defended by counsel; informed on 3 Aug 1949 to prepare defence by 6/7 Aug; trials concluded 14/13 Aug 1949.
Affidavit by Hanumantha Naidu: Accused had means or facilities provided; some declined lawyers; Ramireddy defended some in Case 14.
High Court in appeals noted accused declined lawyers even when offered time.
Amending Regulation 30 Oct 1949: Death sentences by hanging; warrants in form Tribunal thinks fit.
In Case 14, sentence death by hanging; others simply death.
Case 17: Six accused, five also in Case 18; dissenting judgment by one member; fatal blow not by remaining accused Kallur Gowndla Elladu.

legal_issues.text: Whether Special Tribunal had jurisdiction to try petitioners, as order by Civil Administrator did not sufficiently identify cases (esp. charge sheet No.14 dated 20 Jul 1949 for Case 17).
Whether fair trial in Cases 17 and 18 denied due to no opportunity to instruct counsel; undefended throughout.
Whether misjoinder of charges (murder/rioting with unlicensed firearms).
Whether death sentence by hanging illegal; only decapitation per Hyderabad CrPC Schedule IV Form 29.
Whether death sentence execution requires 'manzuri' (assent) of H.E.H. the Nizam under Hyderabad CrPC ss.20,302,307,339.
Whether Supreme Court can grant relief under Art.32 post finality of High Court judgment, via certiorari, prohibition, habeas corpus.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial by Special Tribunal without jurisdiction; Civil Administrator's orders referenced charge sheet numbers vaguely, no names/particulars; no order for charge sheet 14(2) of 20 Jul 1949 (Case 17).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Special Tribunals Regulation; ordinary law requires Magistrate enquiry then Sessions.

petitioner_arguments.text: No fair trial in Cases 17/18: No opportunity to communicate with relations/friends, no counsel offered/appointed; ignorant of rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad CrPC s.271 (right to pleader); Powell v. Alabama.

petitioner_arguments.text: Misjoinder of charges: Unlicensed firearms unconnected to murder/rioting, not same transaction.
Death by hanging illegal; only decapitation per Hyderabad CrPC s.311, Schedule IV Form 29.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad Penal Code s.243; CrPC s.311.

petitioner_arguments.text: No 'manzuri' (assent) of Nizam obtained for death sentences.

respondent_arguments.text: Charge sheet numbers sufficient identification as they contained names/details; Case 17 also transferred (affidavit).
Accused had means/facilities for counsel; declined; lawyers available/willing.
No misjoinder/prejudice; not violation of CrPC.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Abdul Rahman v. King Emperor; Babu Lal v. Emperor.

respondent_arguments.text: Amending Regulation 30 Oct 1949 allows hanging retrospectively; High Court could impose.
'Manzuri' means confirmation; substituted by 'tausiq' in Regulation s.7(2) by Military Governor.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Special Tribunals Regulation s.7; Hyderabad CrPC ss.20 etc.

court_reasoning.text: Misjoinder: Even if defect, not want of jurisdiction but irregular exercise; curable on appeal/revision; High Court affirmed, final.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Basic difference between want of jurisdiction and irregular exercise; no authority for writ on mere non-compliance with procedure.

court_reasoning.text: Death by hanging: Amending Regulation s.2-B retrospective as mode not substantive; High Court upheld under it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mode of execution hardly substantive law.

court_reasoning.text: 'Manzuri' means confirmation; 'tausiq' in Regulation s.7 substitutes; simplifies procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not peculiar to ruler; used for HC/Govt too.

court_reasoning.text: No counsel: Desirable but not vitiate trial per se; appellate court can interfere if negation of fair trial; here accused declined, facilities offered; not clear denial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot lay down rule every unrepresented capital case vitiated; Tribunal should have assigned but evidence shows refusal.

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction: Charge sheet refs sufficient except prima facie Case 17 (14(2)); but even if no jurisdiction, HC affirmed with jurisdiction; finality attaches.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellate court competent to decide jurisdiction rightly/wrongly; order not nullity.

court_reasoning.text: Art.32 relief: Writs for fundamental rights enforcement; certiorari/prohibition inapplicable; habeas not if detention per final criminal sentence; cannot go behind affirmed conviction on affidavits re jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finality of judgments; Constitution not retrospective; cannot reopen closed transactions.

holdings.text: Misjoinder, even if present, does not oust jurisdiction; final by HC.
Death by hanging valid post amendment; retrospective.
No legal right to counsel vitiates trial automatically; facts show no negation of fair trial.
Even assuming no jurisdiction in trial court for Case 17, HC affirmation final; no habeas relief.
Art.32 cannot reopen final pre-Constitution HC judgments; detention lawful.

precedents_cited.relevance: Misjoinder due to 41 offences; broad rule restricted later.
Duty to assign counsel in capital cases for due process; desirable but not automatic vitiation.
Habeas return of detention per criminal sentence sufficient.
Habeas not to controvert criminal sentence return.
No habeas despite repealed statute/errors if no appeal; Crown mercy.
Affidavits ok for no jurisdiction if no prior conviction; went too far ignoring appellate affirmation.
No habeas to challenge jurisdiction post-conviction; jury finding final.

precedents_cited.case_name: Greene v. Secretary of State for Home Affairs
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports no habeas behind criminal sentence.
Calcutta HC: Detention per sentence bars habeas.
Appeal lies even from order without jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bandiram Mookerjee v. Purna Chandra Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal lies even from order without jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wajuddi Pramanik v. Md. Balaki Moral
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal lies even from order without jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kalipada Karmorkar v. Sekher Bashini Dasya
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal lies even from order without jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petitions; power for writs only for fundamental rights enforcement; no retrospective reopening of final judgments.

statutes_cited.name: Special Tribunals Regulation No. 5 of 1358 F (Hyderabad)
statutes_cited.relevance: Constituted tribunals, delegated powers, confirmation by 'tausiq', death by hanging.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Murder penalty includes death; no mode specified.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to pleader; 'manzuri' for sentences; ratification; mode of execution (decapitation pre-amendment).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogous to Hyderabad s.271; finality of appellate judgments.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed all petitions under Art.32 and for special leave under Art.136. Held no relief grantable as High Court judgments final pre-Constitution; even prima facie jurisdictional issue in Case 17 no bar to habeas as affirmed by competent HC; detention lawful per established procedure.

key_quotes.text: There is a basic difference between want of jurisdiction and an illegal or irregular exercise of jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes defects curable on appeal from jurisdictional nullity.

key_quotes.text: It cannot be laid down as a rule of law that in every capital case where the accused is unrepresented, the trial should be held to be vitiated.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits right to counsel; no automatic vitiation.

key_quotes.text: The trend of decisions thus seems to be in favour of the view that if it should appear on the face of the return that a person is in detention in execution of a sentence on indictment on a criminal charge, that would be a sufficient answer to an application for a writ of habeas corpus.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bars habeas review of final criminal convictions.

key_quotes.text: Evidently, the appellate court in a case which properly comes before it on appeal, is fully competent to decide whether the trial was with or without jurisdiction, and it has jurisdiction to decide the matter rightly as well as wrongly.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Appellate affirmation not nullity even if trial lacked jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: Can then a new law or a change in the old law entitle us to reopen a transaction which has become closed and final?
key_quotes.speaker: court
